welcome.data: Warm-Up Prompt: “What kind of data do you think computers use besides text and numbers? Can you think of examples?” Students brainstorm 2–3 types of data they might encounter in a program and share.

aim.data: Objective: Students will be able to identify and use Python's built-in data types, capture user input using input(), convert between types using int(), float(), str(), and write effective inline comments to explain code.

review.data: Ask students to recall what a variable is in Python and how to assign values using =. Live demo: name = "Alex", age = 17. Prompt discussion on what types these are.

relevant.data: Mini-lecture and demonstration with live examples in PyCharm. Cover string, int, float, bool, user input, type conversion, and both single-line and multi-line comments in Python.

interactive.data: Students complete a guided mini-lab: collect name, age, and pizza preference. Convert age to int and print a summary message. Instructor provides real-time support.

ownership.data: Challenge: Students write a program that asks for first and last name, birth year, and favorite number. The program calculates age, multiplies the number by 10, and prints a summary. Instructor provides example solution after student attempts.

resonate.data: Exit Ticket: 1) What function lets you get text input from a user? 2) How do you convert a string to an int? 3) Why are comments important? Students submit answers before leaving.

supplies.data: Computers with Python and PyCharm installed, projector or screen for demos, LMS or handout for mini-lab, and an exit ticket tool like Google Form or Canvas.
